definition: The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA) - comprehensive U.S. federal law governing financial institutions' handling of consumer financial information through privacy protection, data security safeguards, and pretexting prevention.
official_description: Federal law enacted November 12, 1999, requiring financial institutions to explain information-sharing practices and protect sensitive data. Enforced by multiple federal agencies including FTC, Federal Reserve, OCC, FDIC, CFPB, NCUA, and state regulators. Mandates comprehensive privacy notices, information security programs, and pretexting prevention measures. Applies broadly to any business significantly engaged in financial activities.
applicable_to: All financial institutions including banks, credit unions, insurance companies, mortgage brokers, payday lenders, tax preparers, accountants, debt collectors, credit reporting companies, financial advisors, real estate appraisers, retailers offering financial services, higher education institutions (Title IV)
organization_owner: Federal Trade Commission (FTC); Federal Reserve; Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC); Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC); Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB); National Credit Union Administration (NCUA); Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC); State Attorneys General; State Insurance Commissioners
key_features: Three main rules: Financial Privacy Rule (Regulation P), Safeguards Rule (314.4 CFR), Pretexting Protection; Civil penalties up to $100,000 per violation for institutions, $10,000 per violation for officers/directors; Criminal penalties up to 5 years imprisonment; Breach notification requirement (effective May 13, 2024); Multi-agency enforcement framework

definition: GLBA Title V Subtitle A - Privacy Rule requiring financial institutions to provide clear privacy notices describing how customer nonpublic personal information is collected, used, shared, and protected, with consumer opt-out rights for certain disclosures.
official_description: Regulation P implemented by federal banking agencies and FTC, requiring financial institutions to provide privacy notices at account opening and annually thereafter. Notices must describe categories of NPI collected, information-sharing practices, consumer opt-out rights, and safeguarding measures. Distinguishes between consumers (individuals seeking services) and customers (ongoing relationships). Annual notice exemption available if institution meets specific criteria under FAST Act amendments.
applicable_to: All financial institutions collecting, using, or disclosing nonpublic personal information; Applies to both consumer and customer relationships
organization_owner: Federal Trade Commission (FTC); Federal Reserve; OCC; FDIC; CFPB; NCUA
version: Regulation P 16 CFR Part 1016 (effective 2000); FAST Act amendments (December 4, 2015); Updated through 2024
key_features: Privacy notices at account opening and annually; Opt-out rights for non-affiliated third-party sharing; No opt-out for affiliate sharing or contracted service providers; Annual notice exemption under FAST Act for qualifying institutions; Clear and conspicuous notice requirements; Electronic delivery with consumer consent; Distinguishes consumer vs. customer rights

definition: GLBA Section 501(b) and implementing regulations requiring financial institutions to develop, implement, and maintain comprehensive written information security programs protecting customer information confidentiality, security, and integrity through administrative, technical, and physical safeguards.
official_description: FTC Safeguards Rule 16 CFR Part 314 significantly updated in 2021-2023, requiring written information security programs appropriate to institution size, complexity, and data sensitivity. Mandates nine core elements including qualified individual designation, periodic written risk assessments, safeguard implementation, continuous monitoring and testing, employee security training, vendor oversight, program updates, incident response plans, and annual board reporting. 2024 amendments added breach notification requirement.
applicable_to: Non-bank financial institutions under FTC jurisdiction; Higher education institutions (Title IV programs); Any organization significantly engaged in financial services; Exemptions limited for entities under 5,000 consumer records (partial exemption only)
organization_owner: Federal Trade Commission (FTC); Applicable to FTC-jurisdictional financial institutions
version: 16 CFR Part 314 (original 2003); Major amendments effective June 9, 2023; Breach notification effective May 13, 2024
key_features: Nine required elements: Qualified Individual designation, periodic written risk assessments, safeguard design and implementation, continuous monitoring and testing, security awareness training, third-party service provider oversight, program updates based on monitoring, incident response plan, annual written reports to board; Encryption of data at rest and in transit (or effective alternatives); Multi-factor authentication for system access; Annual penetration testing; Biannual (quarterly) vulnerability assessments; Breach notification to FTC within 30 days if 500+ individuals affected

definition: GLBA Section 521 provisions prohibiting obtaining customer information through false pretenses and requiring financial institutions to implement measures preventing unauthorized information disclosure through social engineering, deception, or fraudulent methods.
official_description: Federal protection against pretexting - form of social engineering where attackers use fabricated scenarios to manipulate victims into disclosing sensitive information. GLBA makes pretexting explicitly illegal and requires institutions to implement identity verification procedures, employee training programs, access restrictions, and data shielding measures. Institutions must train employees to recognize pretexting attempts, implement multi-factor verification for high-risk requests, and establish clear escalation procedures.
applicable_to: All financial institutions and their employees; Covers both institutional responsibilities and individual criminal liability
organization_owner: Federal Trade Commission (FTC); U.S. Department of Justice (criminal prosecution); Federal banking regulators
version: GLBA Section 521 (enacted 1999); Implementing regulations updated through 2024
key_features: Prohibits obtaining information via false pretenses or deception; Requires identity verification procedures (knowledge-based, multi-factor authentication, biometric where applicable); Mandatory employee training on social engineering tactics; Access restrictions based on need-to-know; Data shielding procedures (masking account numbers, prohibiting NPI via unsecured channels); Suspicious request escalation and investigation; Monitoring and audit logging; Criminal penalties for pretexting violations; Secondary verification for high-risk information requests
